title: Identification and Filtering of Random Error in Fiber Optic Current Transducer
summary: This paper focuses on the random error problem of fiber-optic current transformers (FOCT) and proposes a time series modeling method to accurately detect and identify various types of random error information. The research uses Wavelet transform and Kalman filtering algorithm to suppress random errors, improving current measurement accuracy.
methodology: Time series analysis and modeling
research_outcomes: The proposed method can accurately detect and identify various types of random error information in FOCT output data, leading to improved current measurement accuracy.

title: Improved Estimation of Parkinsonian Vowel Quality through Acoustic Feature Assimilation
summary: This paper investigates the use of acoustic features to predict the perceived quality of sustained vowels produced by people impaired with Parkinson's disease. The authors develop a regression model that assimilates relevant acoustic features, including recurrence period density entropy (RPDE), Gammatone frequency cepstral coefficients (GFCCs), and modulation spectrogram features, to improve estimation of PD vowel quality ratings.
methodology: The authors employed multivariate linear regression and support vector regression techniques to assimilate feature sets, both with and without feature reduction techniques.
statistics: Linear regression (LR) and support vector regression (SVR) models were used. Statistical methods included Pearson's correlation coefficient and Spearman's rank-order correlation.
research_outcomes: The results showed that the RPDE measure performed the best among all individual features, while a regression model incorporating a subset of features produced the best overall correlation of 0.80 between the predicted and actual vowel quality ratings.

title: Constraints on the variability of quark masses from nuclear binding
summary: This paper explores anthropic constraints on quark masses and the Higgs vacuum expectation value, using recent work on nuclear binding. The authors refine the understanding of the viable range of quark masses that follow from the existence of heavy nuclei, and discuss the implications for fundamental physics.
methodology: The authors use effective field theory to estimate the variation in quark masses that would 'unbind' heavy nuclei. They also consider a simple model for homogeneous nuclear matter to provide more physical insight into the sensitivity of nuclear binding to scalar interactions between nucleons.
research_outcomes: The paper provides anthropically allowed ranges for the masses of the first generation of quarks and leptons, and discusses the implications for fundamental physics.

title: Branes, Anti-Branes and Brauer Algebras in Gauge-Gravity duality
summary: This paper proposes gauge theory operators built using a complex Matrix scalar which are dual to brane-anti-brane systems in AdS5 × S5 space-time. The authors use Brauer algebras to construct the relevant multi-trace Matrix operators and relate them to the physics of brane-anti-brane systems.
methodology: The authors use a combination of gauge theory and gravity dualities, specifically AdS/CFT duality, to propose new gauge theory operators. They also employ Brauer algebras to construct multi-trace Matrix operators.
research_outcomes: The paper proposes new gauge theory operators that are dual to brane-anti-brane systems in AdS5 × S5 space-time. The authors also relate their results to the physics of brane-anti-brane systems and propose a new formula for dual Brauer elements.

title: Speech recognition rates and acoustic analyses of English vowels produced by Korean students
summary: This paper investigates the pronunciation difficulties of English vowels in Korean students using speech recognition software. The study found that Korean students tend to experience difficulty pronouncing certain vowel pairs, and the results may provide pedagogical implications for teaching and evaluating English vowel pronunciation.
methodology: The study used a combination of speech recognition software (Microsoft Word's 'Dictate' feature) and acoustic analyses using Praat. The participants were 30 female Korean students who produced a list of 40 words twice each, which was then analyzed for correct pronunciation rates and formant trajectories.
statistics: Statistical analyses were conducted on the data using R.
research_outcomes: The study found an overall recognition rate of 54.7% and identified specific difficulties in pronouncing certain vowel pairs. The results suggest that speech recognition software can be useful for diagnosing pronunciation problems in English-language learners.

title: Measurement of gamma + c + X and gamma + b + X production cross sections at sqrt(s) = 1.96 TeV
summary: This paper presents the first measurements of differential gamma + c and gamma + b production cross sections at a hadron-hadron collider. The research focuses on understanding the sea quark content of the proton and gluon splitting into heavy-flavour quark pairs, but does not involve any machine learning or artificial intelligence methods.
methodology: The methodology involves using experimental techniques to measure the production cross sections, including data selection, event reconstruction, and purity estimates. The analysis employs triggers that distinguish large depositions of energy in the electromagnetic calorimeter and uses artificial neural networks to identify photons and heavy-flavour jets.
research_outcomes: The paper presents measurements of differential gamma + c and gamma + b production cross sections, which are compared to theoretical predictions. The results show agreement within uncertainties for gamma + b production but a rising discrepancy between data and theory for gamma + c production as p γ T increases.

title: Towards the development of cascaded surface plasmon resonance POF sensors exploiting gold films and synthetic recognition elements for detection of contaminants in transformer oil
summary: This paper presents the development of a multichannel optical chemical sensor based on molecularly imprinted polymers and surface plasmon resonance in a D-shaped multimode plastic optical fiber. The sensor is designed for detection of contaminants in transformer oil, with a focus on simultaneous determination of dibenzyl disulfide (DBDS) and furfural (2-FAL). The paper explores the possibility of using gold films and synthetic recognition elements to enhance the sensitivity and selectivity of the sensor.
methodology: The methodology involves the use of a D-shaped multimode plastic optical fiber with molecularly imprinted polymers as receptors. Surface plasmon resonance is excited by an evanescent wave from an optical fiber, allowing for sensitive and selective detection of contaminants in transformer oil.
research_outcomes: The research outcomes show that the proposed sensor system can detect DBDS and 2-FAL with high sensitivity and selectivity. The results demonstrate the potential of this approach for simultaneous determination of multiple analytes in transformer oil.

title: Coherent Raman Pulses with Quantum-Randomized Polarization
summary: This paper demonstrates the generation of coherent Stokes pulses with randomly-oriented linear polarizations using Raman amplification in diamond crystals. The method produces quantum-random polarization states, which are passively-generated and can be used for applications requiring high entropy rates.
methodology: The authors use a combination of theoretical modeling and experimental techniques to demonstrate the generation of coherent Stokes pulses with randomly-oriented linear polarizations. They employ Raman amplification in diamond crystals, which allows them to produce quantum-random polarization states.
research_outcomes: The paper demonstrates the successful generation of coherent Stokes pulses with randomly-oriented linear polarizations using Raman amplification in diamond crystals. The method produces quantum-random polarization states, which can be used for applications requiring high entropy rates.

title: Data-driven subspace predictive control of adaptive optics for high-contrast imaging
summary: This paper proposes a data-driven method to improve the performance of adaptive optics systems in high-contrast imaging. The proposed controller uses a closed-loop data-driven subspace identification algorithm to predict future wavefront sensor measurements, allowing for near-optimal control and a gain of several orders of magnitude in raw contrast.
methodology: The methodology involves using a linear auto-regressive model to capture the dynamics of the system, with the predictive controller working in a mode space of the deformable mirror. The algorithm is updated online to track non-stationarity and does not require pseudo-open loop reconstruction.
research_outcomes: The proposed controller performs near-optimal control in simulations for both stationary and non-stationary disturbances, with a gain of several orders of magnitude in raw contrast. The algorithm has been demonstrated in the lab with MagAO-X, showing a gain of more than two orders of magnitude in contrast.

title: Differential phase extraction in dual interferometers exploiting the correlation between classical and quantum sensors
summary: This paper presents an experimental demonstration of a method to extract the differential phase in dual atom interferometers, exploiting the correlation between classical and quantum sensors. The authors use a novel approach that combines the advantages of both methods, achieving optimal sensitivity in the differential phase extraction.
methodology: The authors use a combination of classical and quantum sensors to extract the differential phase in dual atom interferometers. They employ a Bloch elevator to launch atomic clouds upwards, which are then separated by a Raman pulse sequence. The atomic phase-shift at the output of each interferometer is given by the sum of the phases of the two counterpropagating Raman lasers.
research_outcomes: The authors demonstrate an optimal sensitivity in the differential phase extraction, limited by detection noise, for in-phase operation of the two interferometers.

title: Feature enhancement for a defocusing structured-light 3-D scanning system
summary: This paper proposes a hybrid method to enhance the calibration and scanning features of a defocusing structured-light 3D scanning system. The method uses a high-order sinusoidal pattern instead of conventional sequential binary patterns, improving reprojection error.
methodology: The proposed system uses a pan-tilt stage carrying a checkerboard to assist the simultaneous calibration of the camera and projector. It also utilizes the multiplication of vertical and horizontal stripe patterns to enhance corresponding features between the camera and projector.
research_outcomes: The experimental results show that the use of the high-order sinusoidal pattern significantly improves reprojection error.

title: Efficacy of the Radial Pair Potential Approximation for Molecular Dynamics Simulations of Dense Plasmas
summary: This paper investigates the efficacy of radial pair potential approximations in molecular dynamics simulations of dense plasmas. The authors compare three RPP models and find that force-matched RPPs are valid for simulating dense plasmas at temperatures above fractions of an eV, while the Yukawa model systematically fails at low temperatures.
methodology: The authors use molecular dynamics simulations to compare the accuracy of three radial pair potential models: force-matched RPPs, Yukawa potentials, and NPA approaches. They analyze multiple metrics of comparison between RPP-MD and KS-MD, including relative force error, ion-ion equilibrium radial distribution function g(r), Einstein frequency, power spectrum, and self-diffusion transport coefficient.
research_outcomes: The authors find that force-matched RPPs accurately describe the results obtained from KS-MD to within a few percent for all cases except low temperature carbon. They also conclude that the Yukawa model appears to systematically fail at describing results from KS-MD at low temperatures.

title: Optical validation and characterization of Planck PSZ2 sources at the Canary Islands observatories. II. Second year of LP15 observations
summary: This paper presents the second and final year of optical follow-up observations for unidentified PSZ2 sources in the northern sky. The authors use a combination of imaging and spectroscopic data to validate cluster candidates, with a focus on improving the purity and completeness of the PSZ2 sample.
methodology: The authors use a multi-step approach to validate cluster candidates, including photometric observations, spectroscopic confirmation, and analysis of Compton y-maps. They also perform a richness study using galaxy counts in clusters.
research_outcomes: The authors find that the purity of the PSZ2 sample has increased from 76.7% to 86.2%, with a corresponding decrease in contamination by interlopers. They also report a clear correlation between unconfirmed sources and galactic thermal dust emission.

title: Optimization of Spot Efficiency of Double-Helix Point Spread Function and Its Application in Intracellular Imaging
summary: This paper proposes an iterative optimization algorithm that combines Laguerre–Gaussian modes and Zernike polynomials to optimize the double-helix point spread function, resulting in a significant improvement in imaging quality. The ML impact is substantial as it is central to the methodology.
methodology: The proposed algorithm uses an iterative scheme to optimize the weight of each Laguerre-Gaussian mode through iteration, reducing the influence of side lobes and attendant aberrations on energy concentration of the main lobe without affecting the characteristics of the defocus double helix.
research_outcomes: The optimization method proposed here could increase the main lobes' light intensity concentration by more than 45%, and could significantly improve the imaging quality.
sources_of_inspiration: Xiaoli Yin et al. added an axicon before the phase modulation plate to suppress the side lobes [13]
The adaptive optical aberration correction method [17] can effectively improve the aberration problems of the imaging system

title: The 750 GeV diphoton excess in unified $SU(2)_L\times SU(2)_R\times SU(4)$ models from noncommutative geometry
summary: This paper discusses a possible interpretation of the $750$ GeV diphoton resonance in unified $SU(2)_L\times SU(2)_R\times SU(4)$ models with gauge coupling unification, imposed by non-commutative geometry. The authors show that the observed cross sections involving the $750$ GeV diphoton resonance could be realized through a SM singlet scalar field accompanied by colored scalars in these unified models.
methodology: The authors use non-commutative geometry to impose gauge coupling unification and restrictively determine the Higgs content of the unified $SU(2)_L\times SU(2)_R\times SU(4)$ models. They then analyze the feasibility of these scenarios using renormalization group equation (RGE) analyses.
research_outcomes: The authors conclude that even though the $750$ GeV diphoton resonance can be accommodated within the NCG motivated unified G $224$ models, the price one has to pay is a certain amount of fine tuning in the sector involving the necessary colored scalars.

title: Vacuum alignment in a composite 2HDM
summary: This paper studies the vacuum structure of a composite two Higgs doublet model based on a minimal underlying theory with 3 Dirac fermions in pseudo-real representations of the condensing gauge interactions. The authors find that the most general CP-conserving vacuum is characterised by three non-vanishing angles, and discuss various mechanisms for generating the top mass.
methodology: The authors use a combination of theoretical analysis and numerical methods to study the vacuum structure of the composite two Higgs doublet model.
research_outcomes: The authors find that the most general CP-conserving vacuum is characterised by three non-vanishing angles, and discuss various mechanisms for generating the top mass. They also present some numerical results on the mass of the Higgs boson candidate.

title: Drastic suppression of superconducting $T_{c}$ by anisotropic strain near a nematic quantum critical point
summary: This paper studies the effect of anisotropic strain on superconductivity in iron-based superconductors. The authors find that anisotropic strain can suppress the superconducting critical temperature, inducing a strain-tuned superconductor to metal quantum phase transition.
methodology: The authors used electrical transport, magnetic susceptibility, and x-ray diffraction measurements to study the effect of anisotropic strain on superconductivity.
research_outcomes: The authors found that anisotropic strain can suppress the superconducting critical temperature, inducing a strain-tuned superconductor to metal quantum phase transition.

title: REX: X-ray experiment on the Water Recovery Rocket
summary: This paper presents a suborbital sounding rocket mission that aimed to classify the Technology Readiness Level of onboard devices designed for space applications. The mission used X-ray telescopes and other sensors, but there is no mention of machine learning or artificial intelligence methods being used.
methodology: The methodology involved using a suborbital sounding rocket to test the performance of various devices in space-like conditions.
research_outcomes: The mission successfully tested the performance of several devices, including X-ray telescopes and other sensors.

title: Quantitative Matching of Forensic Evidence Fragments Utilizing 3D Microscopy Analysis of Fracture Surface Replicas
summary: This paper presents a quantitative framework for forensic comparison of fractured surfaces using 3D microscopy analysis. The authors utilize statistical decision-making tools to quantify the range of features' resolution that generic silicon-type casting materials can capture to replicate the fracture topology.
methodology: The authors use a combination of fracture mechanics and statistics to arrive at a comparison decision. They apply a statistical analysis comparison protocol to 3D topological images of fractured surface pairs and their replicas to provide confidence in the quantitative statistical comparison between fractured items and their replicas.
research_outcomes: The proposed methodology correctly classified the fractured steel surfaces and their replicas with a posterior probability of match exceeding 99.96%. The replication technique shows the potential to accurately replicate fracture surface topological details with a wavelength greater than 20μm.

title: Impact of Warped Extra Dimensions on the Dipole Coefficients in b→sγ Transitions
summary: This paper investigates the FCNC process b → sγ in the minimal Randall-Sundrum model with a brane-localized Higgs sector. The authors derive integral expressions for the dipole coefficients using five-dimensional propagators and compare their results with those obtained in the KK-decomposed theory.
methodology: The authors use a five-dimensional approach to calculate the electro- and chromomagnetic dipole coefficients, including all contributions at one-loop order in the minimal RS model with a brane-localized Higgs sector.
research_outcomes: The paper presents a complete calculation of the electro-and chromomagnetic (quark) dipole coefficients, including all contributions at one-loop order. The authors derive expressions for the dipole coefficients using 5D propagators computed by retaining the full dependence on the Yukawa interactions.

title: Deep learning‐based quantification of PET/CT prostate gland uptake: association with overall survival
summary: This paper presents a deep-learning algorithm for automated quantification of prostate cancer on PET/CT images, which shows good agreement with manual measurements and is significantly associated with overall survival. The algorithm uses a fully convolutional neural network to segment the prostate gland and estimate its volume, as well as calculate various PET-measures.
methodology: The paper employs a deep learning-based approach using a fully convolutional neural network (CNN) to segment the prostate gland on CT scans. The CNN is trained on manually segmented images and then applied to the validation group.
statistics: Sørensen-Dice index, univariate Cox regression model
research_outcomes: The algorithm shows good agreement with manual measurements of prostate volume (SDI: 0.78-0.79) and is significantly associated with overall survival (P = 0.02).

title: Limiting Fragmentation at LHC Energies
summary: This paper investigates the validity of limiting fragmentation in relativistic heavy-ion collisions at Large Hadron Collider (LHC) energies. The authors use a phenomenological three-source relativistic diffusion model to extrapolate pseudorapidity distributions of produced charged hadrons from RHIC to LHC energies, and find that their results are compatible with the limiting-fragmentation conjecture.
methodology: Phenomenological analysis using a three-source relativistic diffusion model
research_outcomes: The authors conclude that limiting fragmentation can be expected to occur in heavy-ion collisions at LHC energies, based on their extrapolations and predictions.

title: Using In-Situ Laboratory and Synchrotron-Based X-ray Diffraction for Lithium-Ion Batteries Characterization: A Review on Recent Developments
summary: This paper reviews recent developments in using in-situ laboratory and synchrotron-based X-ray diffraction for lithium-ion battery characterization. The focus is on improving the understanding of physical and chemical changes in battery materials under working conditions, with a deep analysis of structural evolution, redox processes, and transport properties during cycling.
methodology: The paper discusses in-situ synchrotron-based X-ray diffraction methods for battery materials research, including cell designs and materials, beamline experimental setup details, and future challenges and opportunities for battery technologies.
research_outcomes: The review highlights the importance of understanding degradation processes in lithium-ion batteries and provides a comprehensive overview of recent advancements in improving spatial and temporal resolution using in-situ X-ray diffraction methods.

title: Celebrating 10th anniversary of Photoacoustics
summary: This paper celebrates the 10th anniversary of the journal Photoacoustics, highlighting its growth and impact in the field of physics. The paper discusses various research trends and emerging technologies in photoacoustics, including all-optical optoacoustic systems, laser ultrasound imaging, and advanced methods of photoacoustic microscopy.
methodology: The paper presents a review of the journal's past decade, highlighting its growth and impact. It discusses various research trends and emerging technologies in photoacoustics.
research_outcomes: The paper recognizes the top 10 most influential research papers published in Photoacoustics based on their average annual number of citations.

title: The Photometric LSST Astronomical Time-series Classification Challenge (PLAsTiCC)
summary: This paper presents the PLAsTiCC challenge, an open competition to identify promising techniques for obtaining classification probabilities of transient and variable objects. The challenge aims to balance diverse science goals by engaging a broader community in probabilistic classifications, which are essential for upcoming deep photometric surveys like LSST.
methodology: The paper describes the process used to develop an optimal performance metric for an open classification challenge that seeks probabilistic classifications. The authors compare the sensitivity of metrics of classification probabilities under various weighting schemes and choose a weighted modification of the cross-entropy as a metric for PLAsTiCC.
research_outcomes: The study finds that the chosen metric yields qualitatively consistent results and can be meaningfully interpreted. The authors propose extensions of their methodology to ever more complex challenge goals and suggest guiding principles for approaching the choice of a metric of probabilistic classifications.
